Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as an authoritarian measure that will damage trust in the government.
Previous consultations, such as on mandatory data retention, were ignored despite overwhelming public opposition.
The government should focus on building social trust rather than imposing speech restrictions.
The proposed legislation is viewed as a threat to free speech and could lead to a demoralized society.
The internet's low barrier to entry is crucial, and imposing compliance requirements would stifle innovation and free expression.
Historical examples show that government-imposed restrictions are often bypassed, as with metadata retention and VPNs.
Main Themes: Importance of free speech and open internet
Historical precedent of ignored public consultations
Potential negative societal impact of authoritarian measures
Notable Quotes: This is not a consultation, 'with legislation to be introduced to Parliament later this year', this is transparently an authoritarian steamroll.
An authoritarian crackdown on speech is exactly the wrong thing to do when significant portions of society have extremely strained belief in the credibility of government.
The proposed parasitic takeover of the internet as a propaganda arm of government would be the last straw.
Havenâ€™t you worked out that when an authoritarian government calls something misinformation or disinformation, that automatically signals to the public that it is true?
